awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Physiological and Genetic Responses to Winter in a Willow Leaf Beetle
awd_abstract_narration:
In the Sierra Nevada mountain ranges, like many high altitude environments, snow cover is extremely variable from year to year. Many high altitude animals survive through winter underneath snow that buffers them from extremes of temperature. Many unique and ecologically important animals live in mountainous environments, making it vital to understand and predict impacts of annual differences in snow cover on their population abundances, but as yet we have limited understanding of how snow impacts survival and reproduction of insects and other animals. This project proposes to study physiological and genetic responses to variation in snow cover in a high altitude beetle in the laboratory and the natural environment to understand how snow alters reproductive success during the winter and subsequent summer.  This work will develop a partnership between UC-Berkeley and two Primarily Undergraduate Institutions. Undergraduates at the Primarily Undergraduate Institutions will work with researchers from Berkeley, and Berkeley PhD students will supervise undergraduates from a wide variety of backgrounds and experiences. Thus both groups of students will be exposed to the culture of different educational institutions and will have access to professional contacts outside their usual network. A curriculum module developed from the project for K-12 students will be used to contribute towards their understanding of challenges that organisms face in snowy climates, and this module will be distributed to K-12 teachers through a UC Berkeley-based website.

For high altitude animals, summer is a time of energy gain, while energy conservation is key during winter because resources are scarce and animals rely on energy stores. To resist winter cold, high altitude insects use energy stores to synthesize metabolically expensive cryoprotectants. This may generate a trade-off between cold hardiness and energy conservation. Snow buffers thermal fluctuations, decreasing cold mortality and need for cold hardiness.  However, since temperatures are greater beneath snow than in a snow-free, exposed habitat, there may be increased overall energy demand associated with living under snow.  Due to the energetic trade-off, inter-annual fluctuations in winter snowpack and air temperature will alter selective pressures on overwintering organisms, and may significantly affect growth and reproduction in summer. The central hypothesis is that variation in snow cover alters selective pressures on cold hardiness and energy conservation, influencing physiological performance of overwintering individuals and genetic composition of survivors. The investigators further hypothesize that cold hardiness trades off against future reproduction by depleting winter energy reserves due to energetic costs of cold hardiness. The research will: 1) Measure how variation in snow alters selective gradients on winter-relevant genetic variation in a high altitude beetle, and isolate causal drivers of winter selective gradients. 2) Gain a predictive and quantitative understanding of how cold and energy stressors interact to shape physiological performance during winter and the subsequent summer. 3) Uncover mechanisms underlying interactions between cold and energy stress by asking how single or combined stressors alter reaction norms for energy reserves and cryoprotectants.

Intellectual Merit

The major goal of this project was to improve our understanding of how snow cover impacts winter performance, survival, and genetic variation in the willow leaf beetle Chrysomela aeneicollis as a model for insects in harsh winter environments. Beetle populations inhabit the Sierra Nevada, where snow cover is highly variable. Beetles spend the winter under the soil, and snow insulates the soil, and them, from cold air temperatures, decreasing their winter cold stress and altering energy use. Although high elevations are colder, they may be more snowy, which may mean that soil temperatures are actually warmer at higher elevations due to the buffering effects of snow. This would mean that as snow cover declines, we get the counter-intuitive prediction of colder soils in a warmer world.

Willow leaf beetles are an ideal system in which to address how snow cover affects montane organisms, because of the long history of the focal populations. With this grant, we contributed to two decades of research on population abundance, microclimate measurements, and physiological and genetic studies on this species. This is now one of the best developed study systems for understanding responses to changes in winter climate in any montane organism.

We discovered that snow cover alters elevation gradients in cold exposure. Snow strongly impacts soil temperatures; soils were colder in dry years than snowy ones and cold exposure highest at mid- rather than high elevations (Fig. 1). This suggests that loss of snow cover increases cold stress during overwintering, providing an explanation beetle population declines during droughts. These insights were possible due to the long-term microclimate monitoring networks supported by this and other NSF funding over the past two decades.

We carried out a series of snow manipulation experiments where beetles were buried in soil under either snowy or dry conditions. This allowed us to dig beetles up at defined intervals to study patterns of gene expression. We discovered that beetles need time after emergence to switch metabolism from relying on stored lipids to being ready to digest plant material and initiate reproduction (Fig. 2). The timing of this process is impacted by snow cover, illustrating that variation in snow cover alters not only winter performance but also the timing of growth and reproduction in later life stages.

In addition to differences in gene expression, beetles in snowy plots used more energy over winter and apparently died from energy depletion, while beetles in cold plots had high levels of cryoprotectants, and died with plenty of energy, suggesting that they instead experienced cold mortality (Fig. 3). This supports our hypothesis that snow cover modulates selective gradients on cold stress and energy use.

We next looked at how the genomic make-up of beetle populations varied across the landscape, discovering many genes associated with variation in snow cover (Fig 4). These genes are involved in processes known to be involved in cold stress resistance in insects, including membrane and cytoskeleton organization and ion binding. This is the first demonstration that snow cover variation can cause local adaptation in genes associated with cold stress. We assembled a high quality chromosome-level genome to do this and other work, a product that will facilitate future reserach in this system.

Our findings support the hypothesis that snow is a powerful agent of natural selection, acting to reduce cold exposure when present and changing the conditions for organisms that spend winter in the soil. Thus, if we base our predictions of responses to changes in climate on air temperatures alone, we will get misleading answers. Our research has illustrated that soils in snowy regions will get colder in a warming world due to the buffering effects of snow on the soil, and that these changes will impact the survival, energetics, seasonal timing, and genetic diversity in organisms that overwinter beneath the soil. Understanding the responses of montane organisms to changing climate therefore must take into account changes in snowpack dynamics.

Broader Impacts

This grant supported the research of 36 undergraduate students; 4 PhD students; 3 laboratory technicians, and 2 Masters students. We formed a collaboration with high school teachers and the University of California Museum of Paleontology, and developed The Beetle Project, an adaptable instructional module that uses insects as a model system to illustrate the biological impacts of climate change. The modules engage students with a range of activities designed to increase student understanding of how science works, evolutionary processes, and the impacts of climate change. The full module includes lab activities for high schools using live lady beetles, a paper-and-pencil Data Nugget activity, a case study on the willow leaf beetle research (with student reading guide), and extension lessons for AP Biology classes. We piloted the lab activities in the classrooms of 4 teachers and have translated them into Spanish to increase accessibility.
